Key Arguments: The proposed laws are seen as obscure, frivolous, and Orwellian.
Holding social media platforms responsible for user content is likened to 'shooting the messenger'.
Speech is subjective, and regulating it is challenging and potentially ineffective.
Government regulation of speech is historically slow and ineffective.
The laws could impose a significant financial burden on taxpayers.
Targeting large social media companies may not address misinformation effectively, as misinformation can spread on lesser-known platforms.
The laws could marginalize groups, potentially amplifying their views due to the 'Streisand effect'.
There is a risk of the laws being abused to silence dissent or genuine debate.
The laws are perceived as a threat to democracy and freedom of speech in Australia.
Notable Quotes: I find the idea of these laws frankly quite obscure, frivolous, and slightly Orwellian.
Speech in general is extremely subjective â€“ whether it be hate-speech or misinformation.
These laws in my opinion, are the greatest threat to our democracy and freedom of speech and expression in Australia.
